content: Here is a list of all likely Bitcoin burn addresss I could find through simple examination of address strings.Feel free to reply with other burn addresses or anecdotes about the burns.Amounts are indicative, last updated on 2015-01-08, Grand total: 2617.393 BTC burnedAddresses in order of historical apparition, so multi-addresses messages should be readable.Be warned that some messages can be deemed offensive.Amounts above 1 mBTC comments.author: The00Dustin
comments.body: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=48317.01BitcoinEaterAddressDontSendf59kuE is the first "burn" address I ever heard of...

comments.author: fairglu
comments.body: Quote from: The00Dustin on January 08, 2015, 11:17:54 AMhttps://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=48317.01BitcoinEaterAddressDontSendf59kuE is the first "burn" address I ever heard of...Thanks, added! Seems to be the oldest "meaningful burn address" so far.

comments.author: Q7
comments.body: I'm not sure whether to say if that is a good thing or bad thing but logically, if less is available and demand is strong, that would certainly help to lift and push up the price. But what if more and more bitcoin getting burned when one day it might reach a stage when low numbers in circulation will probably effect it's usefulness as a currency.

comments.author: eid
comments.body: Quote from: Q7 on January 08, 2015, 11:52:15 AMI'm not sure whether to say if that is a good thing or bad thing but logically, if less is available and demand is strong, that would certainly help to lift and push up the price. But what if more and more bitcoin getting burned when one day it might reach a stage when low numbers in circulation will probably effect it's usefulness as a currency.   Fear not for we shall simply add more decimal places!

comments.author: fairglu
comments.body: Quote from: Q7 on January 08, 2015, 11:52:15 AMBut what if more and more bitcoin getting burned when one day it might reach a stage when low numbers in circulation will probably effect it's usefulness as a currency.   Many more bitcoins are likely to get lost unwillingly, because the private keys were lost, than burned on purpose.

comments.author: Madness
comments.body: Quote from: fairglu on January 08, 2015, 10:59:02 AMHere is a list of all likely Bitcoin burn addresss I could find through simple examination of address strings.Feel free to reply with other burn addresses or anecdotes about the burns.Amounts are indicative, last updated on 2015-01-08, Grand total: 2617.393 BTC burnedAddresses in order of historical apparition, so multi-addresses messages should be readable.Be warned that some messages can be deemed offensive.Amounts above 1 mBTC boldedDamn , What are those adresses ? Could anyone please explain to me ? and what does "Burned" adresses or Bitcoin means , they are simply lost or removed from the blockchain or something ?

comments.author: onlinepro
comments.body: Quote from: Madness on January 09, 2015, 09:39:48 AMQuote from: fairglu on January 08, 2015, 10:59:02 AMHere is a list of all likely Bitcoin burn addresss I could find through simple examination of address strings.Feel free to reply with other burn addresses or anecdotes about the burns.Amounts are indicative, last updated on 2015-01-08, Grand total: 2617.393 BTC burnedAddresses in order of historical apparition, so multi-addresses messages should be readable.Be warned that some messages can be deemed offensive.Amounts above 1 mBTC boldedDamn , What are those adresses ? Could anyone please explain to me ? and what does "Burned" adresses or Bitcoin means , they are simply lost or removed from the blockchain or something ? Burned coins means they are sent to address that nobody has private key to.So nobody can't use them.

comments.author: Madness
comments.body: Quote from: onlinepro on January 09, 2015, 09:55:26 AMQuote from: Madness on January 09, 2015, 09:39:48 AMQuote from: fairglu on January 08, 2015, 10:59:02 AMHere is a list of all likely Bitcoin burn addresss I could find through simple examination of address strings.Feel free to reply with other burn addresses or anecdotes about the burns.Amounts are indicative, last updated on 2015-01-08, Grand total: 2617.393 BTC burnedAddresses in order of historical apparition, so multi-addresses messages should be readable.Be warned that some messages can be deemed offensive.Amounts above 1 mBTC boldedDamn , What are those adresses ? Could anyone please explain to me ? and what does "Burned" adresses or Bitcoin means , they are simply lost or removed from the blockchain or something ? Burned coins means they are sent to address that nobody has private key to.So nobody can't use them.So Basically sending Bitcoin to adresses that dosen't exist , just made up from mind ?  I thought that wallets don't allow sending bitcoin to adresses that dosen't exist , at least this is what I heard.Nice to know tho , thank sfor the useful informations man

comments.author: onlinepro
comments.body: Quote from: Madness on January 09, 2015, 10:12:11 AMQuote from: onlinepro on January 09, 2015, 09:55:26 AMQuote from: Madness on January 09, 2015, 09:39:48 AMQuote from: fairglu on January 08, 2015, 10:59:02 AMHere is a list of all likely Bitcoin burn addresss I could find through simple examination of address strings.Feel free to reply with other burn addresses or anecdotes about the burns.Amounts are indicative, last updated on 2015-01-08, Grand total: 2617.393 BTC burnedAddresses in order of historical apparition, so multi-addresses messages should be readable.Be warned that some messages can be deemed offensive.Amounts above 1 mBTC boldedDamn , What are those adresses ? Could anyone please explain to me ? and what does "Burned" adresses or Bitcoin means , they are simply lost or removed from the blockchain or something ? Burned coins means they are sent to address that nobody has private key to.So nobody can't use them.So Basically sending Bitcoin to adresses that dosen't exist , just made up from mind ?  I thought that wallets don't allow sending bitcoin to adresses that dosen't exist , at least this is what I heard.Nice to know tho , thank sfor the useful informations manThey do exist but nobody has private keys to them.

comments.author: The00Dustin
comments.body: Quote from: Madness on January 09, 2015, 10:12:11 AMSo Basically sending Bitcoin to adresses that dosen't exist , just made up from mind ?  I thought that wallets don't allow sending bitcoin to adresses that dosen't exist , at least this is what I heard.Nice to know tho , thank sfor the useful informations manYou can't just make up an address by typing in whatever you want or even by typing in whatever you want from the allowed characters.  The address must meet certain mathematical requirements, but you can make an address that mostly looks like what you want and then finish it off by calculating for those mathematical requirements.  I'm sure this is explained much better in the thread I linked to in the first reply to the OP.Technical version: The address I added in the first reply in the OP ends with f59kuE.  That isn't just random gibberish the first person to send to that address made up.  All or part of that is the checksum (mathematical verification that the address is valid).  The checksum is what prevents you from making something up completely, and it exists primarily to prevent accidental spends to typo addresses (it isn't technically required, but because it exists, it is extremely unlikely that you can type an address wrong and send coins).  The address also must only contain valid characters as defined by base-58 encoding, which prevents that particular address from being all caps (uppercase o and i are not allowed in base-58).

comments.author: Ucy
comments.body: Quote from: thirdkiller on May 13, 2021, 09:20:35 AMWhy do you need this information? I don't quite understand it.I guess the burn addresses are addresses with coins that can never be spent again. The owners probably do this (intentionally/unintentionally) by creating addresses without private keys or addresses they cannot withdraw coins from... then they send coins to them and they coins remain there forever.I don't quite understand why they do this yet, considering that Bitcoin is already scarce.

comments.author: cirosantilli
comments.body: This paper https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.14057 Bitcoin Burn Addresses: Unveiling the Permanent Losses and Their Underlying Causes by MOHAMED EL KHATIB and ARNAUD LEGOUT (2025) looks for unspent low entropy addresses, which are good candidates for burn addresses. They found abot 8k burn addresses and the authors allowed me to publish their result data: https[Suspicious link removed]r/blob/master/data-manual/low-entropy-addresses-khatib-legout.csv The top by total BTC burnt including number of burn transactions can be found with:Code:mlr --csv sort -nr total_received then cut -f address,total_received,nb_transactions then reorder -f address,total_received,nb_transactions,first_apparition_date low-entropy-addresses-khatib-legout.csvThe top 100
